segments.text: Okay, my name is Denny Tudus and today is April the 5th, 1986.
And I'm going to interview my uncle, Raleigh Brotherman III.
And we're just going to go over Vietnam, when he was there, what he did, and just a basic interview.
This is prepared for Terry Anderson.
History 489, Texas A&M University.
Okay, my first question is when did you go to Vietnam?
In September of 68.
September of 68, which would be right around the Tet Offensive.
And were you drafted or did you enlist?
No, I enlisted in the Air Force in 66.
Okay, and when you went to Vietnam, what was your rank?
Sergeant.
Sergeant, okay.
Okay, once you arrived in Vietnam, what was your job?
I was in what they call the military airlift command and it was air passenger service.
It was my career field and I was stationed at Cam Ranh Bay primarily.
Our main function was to get troops in and out of the country
And then once they were in the country, to move them around the smaller aircraft.
And our job was to set up the different airfields and keep them secured for in-country travel.
And also manage the in and out
ports like Cameron Bay and Saigon and Da Nang.
Is this I Corps 3?
No, I was in 2 Corps.
I spent most of my time in 2 Corps.
Cameron was my home base, but we went out to little places like Nha Trang and Pleiku.
Pleiku was around here.
A little bitty handlets in the area for the smaller aircraft like the C-123 and C-130s.
And the lock is not too far from there.
I can't even think of it.
That's sort of a rough draft of a map.
But the whole idea was for us to keep track of
who was where.
It was air transportation for all the services at that time and civilians.
Were y'all ever in combat?
We were non-combatants, but we were armed when we were away from Cameron.
Cameron was such a big, secure base
In the Air Force wisdom, they felt like we shouldn't be armed.
We'd probably kill each other.
Watch the airmen run around with rifles.
When we left the base to go into the field, we were always armed.
Any combat we were in was primarily just defensive because whenever it was dark, Charlie would come out.
It was harassment fire from rocket attacks and stuff like that.
And a couple of times they got into Cameron or rocketed Cameron and just tear up our runway a little bit and go away.
But it was a few anxious moments.
But we weren't out physically looking for Charlie.
He was always trying to mess up our little party.
So you were pretty lucky as far as that's concerned.
You're fortunate enough not to be there.
Do you think that we belonged there at the time?
Yeah, we pretty much committed ourselves to the domino theory that if Vietnam fell then Cambodia and Laos and everybody else would go with it, would fall into communism.
So we felt like we needed to be there to stem the red tide.
But did you think that we should have declared war?
Because there's always the gripes of limited power of Congress.
It was always considered a police action.
But when you're over there, you don't think in terms of police action.
You always think you are at war.
It was always a war to us.
And we were just under the assumption
that we were there to win the war.
And all these artificial constraints that were put on us.
Do you consider yourself as a hawk or a dove?
Well at the time by definition I would have been a hawk because I wanted to be there and I didn't see any benefit to the peace movement
Because in my estimation, it was not a peace movement, it was just a good excuse to smoke dope.
Yeah.
Lots of that.
That's what I was going to ask you about, you know, drugs over there played an important role towards the later years.
Probably because it probably cost us the war, among other things, that the... Fragging.
That dope was just all over the place.
Uh-huh.
And it was my theory that
that the Red Chinese, at least, were smart enough to keep that dope coming.
And that was because that was their best weapon, to keep the American guys high and disoriented to the point where they could just walk right over it.
Yeah, they didn't care.
That's interesting.
I think that a lot of the officers that were sent there were so gung-ho, and we've read several accounts,
And in the readings that we've had, that some of these green officers went and the tour of duty was only, you know, what, 12 months, 18 months?
12 months.
And 12 months isn't enough time.
You know, once you've gone through nine months, you just have three months left to serve and you're not going to risk your life for anybody or anyone.
But when the green lieutenants and what have you would arrive, they'd be so gun-ho.
And their troops wouldn't, you know, they'd be short timers.
Towards the end of the war, a lot of fragging occurred where people that may have been on drugs were killing their officers just for the sake of saving their own lives, I guess.
It's pretty, I don't know.
Yeah, it's pretty bizarre in the field where, because we've,
and pulling these guys out on the field, they were almost hardly recognizable as human beings.
Of course, by contrast, we were a little, I guess, since we had it, much better.
We were at least modestly clean, and these guys were coming up with this absolutely

And you could tell that they lost their, a lot of their human instincts or just the human social ability because they were just, they had experienced so much and had just been in, for months of just being in the filth and... Plus their resources.
And whatever they've seen, they've just gone to, what I'm trying to get at is that they had gotten their more baser instincts, more animalistic,
And it wouldn't surprise me if a lot of guys got wiped out because somebody looked off to somebody and it was just convenient, the person was conveniently disposed of.
And I'm sure once they got back to the States that they got, a lot of them turned away from that because they were away from that hostile environment, or the primitive environment.
Plus, they're so young.
The average age was 19.
We had warrant officers.
The Army promoted their guys so fast that they had captains that were helicopter or gunship pilots in the Army that had to be in their early 20s, early, early 20s.
And they just, they were barely, you know, old enough to be flying an aircraft.
Must have been held up from enlistee or craftee to captain.
Not even old enough to shave in a lot of cases.
How do you think LBJ, whose administration was in charge while you were there, how do you think he handled the war?
I kind of think LBJ would have wanted us to win this thing.
I've never had real high esteem for LBJ, but he may have been too much of a diplomat.
You think he was involved too deeply?
You think he should have let Westmoreland run the show more so than he did?
Well, his administration, his House and Senate ran the war.
Westmoreland, I don't think, had that much to say about it.
Either Johnson, not Johnson personally, but the government, the U.S. Congress held us back way too much.
Kept their heel on us and would not let the Air Force and Marines do their job.
And there have been a lot fewer deaths.

And a lot fewer men of our guys in the field if we could have had more of an air war and more of a... We could have bombed the place to oblivion if we really wanted to win the war in just a matter of minutes.
But all that we ended up doing is just sending young guys out there to die in sort of a war of attrition.
Do you think we should have bombed the cities?
instead of staying into bombing the Ho Chi Minh Trail and the borders?
I don't know that we should have gone in and deliberately looked to wipe out entire cities.
Civilians, whatever.
Because our whole idea was to do more than stem their supply lines.
And we need to do it.
attack that angle of it, the supply lines, to the Ho Chi Minh Trail.
But also, we never seemed to really get interested in the tunnel network that was all under Vietnam that we now find out was just very pervading that we went everywhere in Vietnam.
It was like fighting a bunch of ants, if that's what they were referred to.
These people were so...
These people have been at war for so long

that they know the tricks and they kind of revert, like I said before, back to their, to an animalistic state because they can survive for months underground and got up in trees and wherever else if you want.
You wouldn't even be looking for a human being.
And they, we were fighting on their turf right in their backyard.
They knew where everything was.
And until we got into a real,
take-no-prisoners, kick-ass-and-take-names attitude, we weren't about to win that war.
The take-no-prisoners reminds me of body counts.
You would tend to agree, I imagine, that the body counts were false.

always incorrect well that's all come out now it's uh everything was so much was i i'm busy so much of so much emphasis was put on body count and uh where i was on the beach and stuff whenever we'd uh
Whenever we would be invaded, it was just to see all the bodies piled up and burning or whatever it is.
Then somebody over there trying to get a good accurate estimate of how many bodies were taken as compared to how many of our lives were lost.
Usually in our area, we were so well
We didn't lose anybody.
You're lucky to be protected, that's for sure.
Okay, were you aware of any of the pacification programs?
The pacification programs pretty much ran up through 68 through 69, and after Tet, they
pretty much fell to pieces.
And by pacification, I mean the strategic hamlets and all of these different programs that were set up to win the hearts and minds of the Vietnamese.
Or wham, whammam, as it's referred to in lots of books.
I guess I'm totally ignorant of that program.
OK.
I had no idea it was going on as such.
You know, the strategic hamlets, they were building.
hamlets for the Vietnamese to live in.
They had to live there at night.
They were totally removed from their ancestral lands, put in little encampments, which we'd call basically a reservation, kind of if you look back to how the Indians were treated.
They were corralled, placed in these hamlets, were guarded.
And if they were seen outside of the hamlet's perimeter at night, they were shot.
They were considered VC.
I don't see how you can win the hearts and minds of someone when you're constraining them so much.
But you weren't aware of any of this?
Well, if that's what was the little village outside of Cam Ranh was supposed to be,
It was for obvious reasons why somebody approached the village after nightfall.
It was assumed that they were hostile.
And that was pretty much the way everybody had to be.
Because with the problem of cross-racial identification,
There's not going to be any American soldier who's going to know which Vietnamese is good or bad.
So we had to take, like in our encampment in Cam Ranh, the Koreans were right next to us.
And they guarded, and we guarded the bay.
And it was just an unwritten law that if the sampans came in at night beyond a certain point, or in the daytime, it doesn't matter, it was sort of like Gaddafi's line of death.
You came in too far, you were going to get blown out of the water.
And then you were a dead man.
And they knew that.
They were out there fishing.
They were supposed to be out there fishing.
They were not to come to shore.
Or on our turf, so to speak.
And they were just... Everybody knew that they got... And they were just... Every day, somebody would get blown out of the water.
Because they got too close.
Because they got too close.
And that was... And everybody had to understand that we were at war.
And their own personal...
little inconveniences could not be taken into consideration because we don't know who they are.
Do you think the media played an important role in the war?
Yes, they did.
They created such a
an anti-war sentiment, and such an anti-G.I.
sentiment.
And every night you could see what happened during the day in Vietnam, or in David.
David Ford.
David Ford.
And created such a hostile environment toward

our winning the war or our being there that we never had a chance to build up a national spirit well the national spirit was there at first it just it uh dissipated after after tet when when we saw that we weren't winning the war like everybody assumed
That's when the kids at home became more aggressive?
I don't know that we ever had.
I can go back to when I first started hearing about Vietnam as a possible place for me to go.
It was in high school when I was 63 or so.
People were already going to Vietnam, Marines and stuff like that, and people like that.
Not knowing that we'd been there since the 50s, or actually never.
Yes, it's an advisory capacity.
And people are already starting to go there and die.
And there was never the feeling that, like, I'm sure that soldiers or young men got during the World War II era, where it was really a good thing to go do this.
That we were fighting for a good cause.
And I attribute that to the way that the media handled it and the peace movement and just the liberal attitude that the media has had at that point and continues to this day.
That we can't get into a conflict without
first checking with the media to make sure it's all right with them.
They want to be involved in everything and they want to downplay the...
The military as well.
They're just trying to make us look like fools and like really bad guys because we were just trying to practice basic survival.
And there was nothing that the GIs
could get excited about.
It was just that they were going to try to do anything that good to stay alive.
They were not fighting for their country.
So the media showed the students at home that, hey, this isn't where you want to be.

You think that they don't want to support that the people at home, after seeing some of these clips and newsreels and hearing Walter Cronkite and Morley Safer and Keys Beach and all these other guys that were sending back messages or clips of film, you think that these little reels that were sent home made the people here, students, young high school and college age kids, feel that it wasn't something that they would want to participate in?
No.
They really, it was a very, very ugly war by the very nature of guerrilla warfare.
It's just absolute.
The atrocities and the things that we do to kill and maim people.
And then we've met enough that it actually happens, but then to portray it
on the silver screen every night.
It really, really, really preys on people's minds and senses.
Okay.
How did you feel when you got back home?
Glad to be home.
Glad to be alive.
I didn't feel so much like that everybody hated me.
like I hear today so much that some people have a hard time getting over the war.
And I was just glad to be alive.
I felt like I had aged a hundred years.
I'd seen more than I ever needed to see.
But everything was forgotten.
It was just like once
With the night I left in Cam Ranh, we were back in Cam Ranh now, where it was relatively safe, but things have deteriorated.

The whole year I was there, we had been in more and more attacks, and the base that was supposed to be so strong was, we were getting satchel charges on every other night, thrown into everything, and everybody was just on pins and needles as to what was gonna blow up next.
And the night I left, we were going, we were on red alert again.
And I was just thinking, oh God, here I am.
The last night here, we're all going to get blown away.
And just wait, just wait for the sun to come up because that seemed to be after like four o'clock in the morning.
Everything settled down.
It's just like everybody said, well, enough for the night, we're going home.
But the time came for me to finally
I'd get on the aircraft, or Freedom Bird as they call them.
Did you go to Japan from there?
No, we went straight on back.
I don't think we even stopped.
It was non-stop.
And then once you were back in the States, you just... Landed at Tacoma, Washington.
And got off the plane.
And went over to see...
my guys in the military airline command section to see if they could get me on a hop back to San Antonio.
A hop is a military plane.
It's any kind of aircraft to get back to San Antonio.
But you were already out of the military as of that point?
Oh, no, no, no.
I still had, I had an Air Force have a four-year enlistment.
Okay.
And I had about a year left
And so I was on my 30-day leave, and I was going to the Laredo Air Force Base from there.
But it was...
Were you glad that you went when you did?
Oh sure, I was glad to be.
I volunteered to go to Vietnam, and I was sent to Vietnam, probably.
And I figured that I would probably, I had just a good chance of making it alive.
It does not make it.
And it was a long 365 days or whatever it turned out to be.
But I got back and it just wasn't, it didn't prey on my memory that much.
Nightmares once in a while, there's nothing excruciating it.
But you feel fortunate that you didn't have to get into the, say, more of the jungle-type fighting?
Oh, yeah, sure.
It could have been really...
I think that's the way it was just ordained for me, not to be in the...
Because I could have easily been, when I was at the draft board, well, when you enlist, everybody's in all one big room to swear in.
The draftees, the enlistees, everybody takes the same oath.
And they're all in Army, Navy, Marines.
And when it's time to split up, we all go our separate ways.
And I could have easily been in with that group that were drafted into the Army.
And probably most of those guys are dead.
Because probably most of them went to...
In 66, everybody got called up.
My 2S deferment for school was worthless.
Unless I was going to do something like be a doctor or something like that.
That would be really, really important.
So I probably would have been drafted anyway.
And it was better to enlist than to be drafted?
Yeah, I couldn't help it.
I didn't want to go in the Army.
You could pick your branch of service.
And an Air Force, I might learn something there.
It wouldn't be just cannon fodder.
Well, have you kept up with any of the current events?
Do you think that all the Vietnam veterans programs are really going to help the vets, like the people that have suffered from Agent Orange?
Yeah, it seems like you always hear that.
I wondered if I could, because they use that stuff all the time, this pesticide, or antifoliant, and they sprayed the hell out of us all the time.
I wondered if I would...
But I wonder if we're not making too much of all that.
These veterans programs, there's obviously a lot of guys out there who feel like they've been slighted.
But there are guys out there who are going to feel like they're slighted anyway.
So my way of thinking is it's over and done with.
You've got to go on with your life.
You can't just keep living in the past all the time.
If some of these guys have real serious mental problems, what's it called, delayed syndrome?
Vietnam syndrome.
Some kind of post-trust.
Then they should deal with it.
And not keep dressing up like a...

in their fatigues and having parades because that's just there may be a few guys in there who are really really sincere about this and then the rest of them are just hangers on in there to collect on what everybody is going to collect on so you just assume put it aside and go forward we end up in Nicaragua or Israel then hell let's go let's not keep thinking we're going to
to hold up Vietnam and Korea and all these other things as being a history repeating itself.
They're not the same.
It's a different mindset.
Everything is different about it.
We have more at stake in Nicaragua.
I mean, this is pretty close to us.
It's a whole lot closer than Vietnam.
People say that we shouldn't have lost Vietnam, but Vietnam didn't mean as much to us, I guess, as Nicaragua's going to mean.
Fighting the Chinese is one thing.
We're not going to have, you know, we couldn't afford to fight the Chinese at that time.
I don't believe.
That's one thing about all these Rambo movies and all these other, the hell of it is, we still live, we still lose.
No matter what you do, and no matter what we say, what we could have done, we still lost it.
Yeah.
And so we had to deal with that and not lose another one.

But the next time we're involved in something, if we do get involved in Nicaragua, you don't think that for a minute that we're going to fight it or make the same mistakes that we made in Vietnam, do you?
I think we better not.
I think that if we do, I'm moving to some other country.
So it's the...
soldier in Vietnam had his tour, his 12-month tour, I think that'll change, don't you?
Because people in World War II were sent to fight and win the war.
Yeah, I just recently heard the rhetoric about that.
12 months is a long time.
But I guess the feeling is now that
In World War II, they kind of just stayed in the war, like you said, until it was won.
And all this turnover may have had a deciding effect on the outcome.
I never really thought of it until just recently.
Well, you'd think if you had put in six months or nine months of heavy fighting, and then all of a sudden you realized you only had, you know,

three more months to go it uh... you'd lose your zest for fighting you'd become more kicked back yeah i guess that's i think korea started that when they were on the point system with so many after you accumulated so many points for for being there for maybe some other meritorious actions you got to leave early leave earlier
I think the attitude should be we stay there until it's over.
Well, is there anything else that you could add?
What was your rank when you got back?
Had you advanced at all?
I was still a sergeant.
Because in the Air Force, they pretty well, I was a sergeant E3.
That was the enlisted rank number three from the bottom.
And you didn't come out of the Air Force at that time with any higher rank after four years in E4, or Staff Sergeant.
That just was sort of the unwritten law.
Unless you did something awfully, awfully, awfully meritorious or wonderful, or they wanted you to reenlist so bad that they would give you an extra strike.
So by the time I got back to the States, I ended up a staff sergeant.
But it didn't mean anything because I was on my way out anyway.
But the rank in the Air Force wasn't as necessary

or wasn't as changing in the Army, in the Air Force as it was in the Army, because the Army guys, they were losing people, either to death or they're getting out, because they only had a two-year enlistment.
So those guys during the wartime experience could find themselves promoted way ahead of anybody, because they just needed ranking people, like the ones that they lost.
Did you think that the black market over there was a detriment to our country?
So I know you got a stereo.
Didn't you get a stereo over there?
Oh, no, I bought that in Hong Kong.
Oh, did you really?
Okay, I thought... That was all legitimate.
The only black market that we're talking about is a... Jeez, you know, we're...
If somebody could do an exercise...
Sorry about the dog barking.
We're just trying to take care of that.
But we're going to go ahead and continue.

If it ever is known about the civilians and actually whoever else was involved and all the goings on over there with the civilian contractors and the military and all the goods and services that were passed back and forth,
You call it corruption, you call it spoils of war, you call it just trying to make things a little bit nicer for you over there while you're over there.
You trade an air conditioner for a jeep or a jeep for a surfboard or something.
Whatever you can do to make life a little more palatable.
That's not exactly black, black market.
When I think of black market, I think of all the... People that were making money.
Oh, yeah.
That's a very lucrative... War is always a lucrative proposition for somebody.
When I think of black market, for instance, the dope that went... That was one place...
I only had maybe a few semesters of college at that point, so I really wasn't into the college scene yet, and the dope scene was getting pretty well fired up on all the campuses at that point.
And if there's anything that kept me from ever really getting, I guess, delivered from being involved in the dope scene was seeing what happens to people who
Who were on it.
Who were on it and who were actually, they lost their lives because of it.
It really wiped out so many guys because a lot of this marijuana and Cambodian red and all that really high-powered stuff that was over there.
Some of it was laced with opium, which would kill you.
It would get you wasted.
But, yeah, there were some of the guys who were just so blitzoid by the time they got back there, they didn't know who they were.
And I made a conscious decision at that point, I would never get involved in this stuff.
How come the Army didn't do anything about it?
It seems like, you know, we've read articles in our readings that say that everybody was aware of it going on, but nothing was done about it.
And you could, if you brought it up, it was just, you know, your...
you were just put aside, or you know, whatever comments you made were just, they were, you know, they would acknowledge your, you know, remarks or questions, but they'd never do anything about it.
To me.

Well, of course, the way anybody took it seriously, you know, they were aware of it, because we'd wiped out, our forces had wiped out VidCon soldiers who were just kind of laying around doing the opium thing.
And they were so stoned that they didn't offer any resistance.
But that's also how they fought a lot too.
They were such militarily superior fighters.
But sometimes don't you think that they were just so high that that made them much more of a fighting machine?
Could be.
Because I know if I was like that, you know, confronted with the...
you know, war, I think that I wouldn't want to feel any pain.
If I knew I had chances of dying, I wouldn't want to feel any pain.
Yeah, and there's no telling how much of that stuff relates with some type of poison to kill all of our troops.
So that aspect of the black market existed, and then whatever the GIs could make out of selling
from the Army Air Force Exchange Service to the locals, making a few bucks here and there.
So that's why some... Whatever, prostitution went on, whatever.
All that stuff had to also not only be morally incorrect, let's say,
But the Vietnamese probably got to look at us and say, look at these guys.
They're just here to exploit our country as much as they can.
There's no high-mindedness here.
There's no great cause.
They're just here.
And by that same token, the Vietnamese, boy, once one of these rice farmers has seen the bright lights of Saigon, he ain't going back.
He's got a few bucks in his pocket now because he traded in a bunch of beer cans to somebody so they could make grenades out of them.
It's just always a way to make a buck in Vietnam.
So the Vietnamese didn't hold a very high opinion of Americans.
We didn't have any high opinion of them.
We thought they were cowardly.
You never want to be caught in a firefight with the Vietnamese as your backup because they were just as cowardly as they could be.
And we felt that all they were out there for was to make a buck off the GIs.
Because they'd sell you anything and everything.
And there was no, we never got the feeling that we were there to
protect their democracy because we're looking at people who had no concept of democracy or they had no concept of anything beyond basic survival.
Well, what else is there that you'd like to add?
Do you think that there's anything I've left out that may be important?
This is my first interview and when it comes to

war you can't really do you think that students ought to be taught you know a class about Vietnam or do you think this is a good how do I say it you think it's worth students it's unusual that somebody would make a course out of a
out of a conflict, but of course if we learned something about it, because you never hear about Korea.
If our situation were changed to a certain point, and I was interviewing my uncle who was a veteran of Korea, that never happened.
It was such a dull little
But we won that one, too.
Well, nobody won that one.
We just sort of stood two of us up side and said, OK, let's just quit.
I guess.
It wasn't really a defeat, but then it wasn't any decisive victory, because there's still a North Korea.
But that was also another one of those wars that was a guerrilla warfare.
And it was probably just as nasty and just as hard fought and unlike the big World War II.
After coming off that resounding victory in World War II, this must have been a real letdown for a lot of the guys that were involved in it.
Of course, the frosting on the cake would have been a bit loud.
But if there's anything to be learned about it, there's just so much.
We just had so many presidents that all took a shot at trying to do something.
I found the class very interesting because, like I say, when I was young, I saw it on TV.
And it's just something that I never grasped until I finally started reading about it and realized how badly we screwed up.
and how it's affected the lives of millions of Americans.

And I'm sure whenever veterans or anybody sit around over a glass of beer and start a friendly conversation about it, and you start talking about the traditional war story and how you embellish it over the years, it gets a little bit better and better and better and better.
The frustrating part is that once you talk about it, it just brings up old, old stuff, and you still lost the war.
Yeah.
It doesn't matter.
You can just sit there and we can complain about Johnson and the Congress and the corruption and this and that and the other thing, but it doesn't change the outcome.
So it seems if there's any futility in discussing it or having a course in it, it's just that we...
We need to learn not to make the mistake again.
Yeah, that's probably what we'll learn out of it.
Well, I guess that'll do it.
I appreciate you helping me out.
My pleasure.
And, gosh, I hope I don't have to go do anything like that.
Learn to speak Spanish.
Yeah.
Thanks a lot.
Okay.
Bye.
